newsitem.title: FINLAND: MERITA SEES SCANT DEMAND FOR 2004 BOND IN AUCTION.
newsitem.headline: MERITA SEES SCANT DEMAND FOR 2004 BOND IN AUCTION.

text.p: Merita Bank said the current negative market sentiment was likely to dampen interest in Thursday's auction of the Finnish 9.50 percent serial 2004 bond.
"Recent market unrest is mainly driven by EMU speculation. We view the current situation as too risky and do not recommend participation," Merita said in a pre-auction comment on Thursday.
From a fundamental point of view, Merita said the auction would be a clear buying opportunity.
"The monetary policy outlook in Europe is still strongly supportive of bond markets," Merita said.
Improving government finances together with an extremely good liquidity situation for institutional investors should be supporting the bond market, Merita said.
"Furthermore, there is hardly any doubt that Finland would be among the first countries (joining EMU) if EMU starts on time," it said.
At 1220/1020 GMT, the 2004 bond yield was quoted at 5.92 percent, up 12 basis points from Wednesday's 5.80 percent close.
The auction results are due after 1330/1130 GMT. In the previous auction on February 13, the State Treasury raised 3.03 billion markka at a yield of 5.46 percent.
